name: LIBERTARIAN NATIONAL COMMITTEE, INC., Appellant v. FEDERAL ELECTION COMMISSION, Appellee
name_abbreviation: Libertarian Nat'l Comm., Inc. v. Fed. Election Comm'n

court.name: Court of Appeals of the District of Columbia

pin_cites.parenthetical: "Political 'free trade' does not necessarily require that all who participate in the political marketplace do so with exactly equal resources."
"Political 'free trade' does not necessarily require that all who participate in the political marketplace do so with exactly equal resources."
"Political 'free trade' does not necessarily require that all who participate in the political marketplace do so with exactly equal resources."
stating that the LNC's "merits briefing [is] bereft of even a molecule of competitive disadvantage theory" and arguing that "it is absurd for the [Commission] to insist" otherwise
quoting Brown v. Entertainment Merchants Ass'n , 564 U.S. 786, 802, 131 S.Ct. 2729, 180 L.Ed.2d 708 (2011)
quoting Brown v. Entertainment Merchants Ass'n , 564 U.S. 786, 802, 131 S.Ct. 2729, 180 L.Ed.2d 708 (2011)

"The premise of our adversarial system is that appellate courts do not sit as self-directed boards of legal inquiry and research, but essentially as arbiters of legal questions presented and argued by the parties before them."
" Citizens United left open the possibility of an as-applied First Amendment challenge, but only if the donor proved that revealing its identity would probably bring about threats or reprisals."
explaining that "a contribution limitation surviving a claim of associational abridgment would survive a speech challenge as well"
explaining that "a contribution limitation surviving a claim of associational abridgment would survive a speech challenge as well"

" Citizens United left open the possibility of an as-applied First Amendment challenge, but only if the donor proved that revealing its identity would probably bring about threats or reprisals."
explaining that self-inflicted harm "does not amount to an 'injury' cognizable under Article III," nor is it "fairly traceable to the defendant's challenged conduct"

"The district court immediately shall certify all questions of constitutionality of [FECA] to the United States court of appeals for the circuit involved, which shall hear the matter sitting en banc."
requiring the Commission to issue written advisory opinions upon request

rejecting a speech restriction as "fatally underinclusive" under intermediate scrutiny
quoting R.A.V. v. City of St. Paul , 505 U.S. 377, 387, 112 S.Ct. 2538, 120 L.Ed.2d 305 (1992)
quoting R.A.V. v. City of St. Paul , 505 U.S. 377, 387, 112 S.Ct. 2538, 120 L.Ed.2d 305 (1992)

rejecting a speech restriction as "hopelessly underinclusive" under strict scrutiny because it drew distinctions between prohibited and permissible categories of speech in a way that was not justified by the interests asserted by the government
